parentTaskName: ISO/IEC TR 12791 - Treatment of unwanted bias in classification and regression machine learning tasks
taskDescription: Documenting methods to prevent and mitigate risks related to unwanted bias in AI systems.

taskItems.title: 1. Acceptance Criteria Definition
taskItems.description: Before evaluating an AI system, determine appropriate acceptance criteria, including tolerances for functional correctness for different at-risk groups.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
Functional correctness is understood as the degree to which a product or system provides the correct results with the needed degree of precision.

 Relevant AI stakeholders should be included in the definition process.

 For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

taskItems.title: 2. Acceptance Criteria Justification
taskItems.description: Justify the choice of acceptance criteria in consideration of the risk management process.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
Acceptance criteria should be documented in the context of the intended use and operating conditions. Acceptance criteria for the system should be testable. Where acceptance criteria are specified in relation to ML model outputs, they shall be specified in a quantitative manner. For example, AI stakeholders can specify a limit for false positive or false negative predictions. These predictions can form failure criteria that are the lower bound of acceptance. 

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

taskItems.description: Provide evidence that you ensured that data labels or documentation of a data set enable data to be evaluated for unwanted bias.

taskItems.title: 4. Metadata
taskItems.description: If the training data does not directly contain an identifier that explicitly links each record to an at-risk group, provide metadata to the data quality checking process if the group is identifiable. In that case, upload the metadata here.

taskItems.title: 5. Test Completion Report
taskItems.description: Document the test approaches used in a test completion report in accordance with ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-3:2021, 7.4.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
The test completion report shall include criteria for when verification and validation activities are repeated, including continuous monitoring.

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

taskItems.title: 6. Data Source Evaluation
taskItems.description: Where appropriate, evaluate and document the following aspects of each data source: completeness, accuracy, collection procedures, timeliness, consistency.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
Where appropriate for the use case, the following aspects of each data source shall be evaluated and documented:

- Completeness, including the number of missing features for each group of relevant stakeholders.
- Accuracy, including the amount of inaccurate data contained within the data set, and the amount of inaccuracy for each group of relevant stakeholders.
- Collection procedures, including the lineage of the data, and the collection, input or labelling mechanism.
- Timeliness, including the effect of the time of collection on accuracy.
- Consistency, including labels.

Further information on data quality measures can be found in ISO/IEC 5259-2.

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

content.Data Consistency Notes: Mix of synthetic and real data

taskItems.title: 7. Mechanisms for Labelling Quality
taskItems.description: Implement mechanisms to ensure labelling or annotation is of sufficient quality to meet AI system objectives, including where it is performed by humans. Please upload your annotation guidelines or other labelling quality assurance mechanisms here.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
This can include:

- Developing questions with known answers to provide a quality measure.
- Conducting sample checks.
- Providing clear instructions or training to humans.
- Mechanisms for humans to provide feedback.
- Evaluating statistical bias in automatically produced labels or annotations.
- Comparing labels created by multiple humans on the same data.

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

taskItems.title: 8. Static Testing
taskItems.description: Conduct data quality evaluation in accordance with ISO/IEC 5259-4:-, 6.3, including measuring training data quality for each at-risk group that has been identified in relation to unwanted bias.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
Organizations can identify the profile of the available training data and validate whether the distribution of a specific variable is accurate. An example of this is identifying that records of a certain age group have been used for training, when a different spread of ages is expected in production data.

This activity can aim to validate the potential for selection bias, sampling bias, and coverage bias, but cannot do so exhaustively, as it is limited by the knowledge of the evaluator.

Organizations can identify stages in the data preparation process that can potentially introduce bias through 'missing data'. For example, if specific data items are not available consistently across an input data set, organizations can impute that information for the remaining records or they can remove it. If the absence of that data item is correlated with specific groups of records, this can result in unwanted bias that would not normally be detected in machine learning model testing.

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

taskItems.title: 10. Dynamic Testing of AI System
taskItems.description: Conduct dynamic testing of the AI system to determine if it exhibits unwanted bias and evaluate functional correctness for at-risk groups.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
Dynamic testing in this context comprises both conventional techniques, where given inputs generate expected outputs, and measurement approaches that show whether the system is behaving statistically as expected or as intended. These tests are designed based on the expected input data.

The degree to which test data are representative of the expected variety of input data provides a measurement of test coverage.

It is important that the system is considered as a whole, and it is not solely the ML component that is identified. This is because bias can be introduced in the data preparation and data processing steps, as well as in the user interface.

The testing should be comprehensive enough to be representative of the expected input data in production usage.

Deploying an AI system to a different environment or a different target population can change the degree to which it exhibits unwanted bias.

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).

content.Definition: Measures the ratio of positive outcomes for one group compared to another.
content.Use: Indicates whether certain groups are unfairly disadvantaged.
content.Justification: Reflects fairness in the AI system's decision-making; aligns with ISO/IEC TR 24027.

content.Definition: Measures the difference in true positive rates across groups.
content.Use: Evaluates whether all groups have equal access to positive outcomes.
content.Justification: Ensures fairness in the systemâ€™s predictive performance across at-risk groups.

content.Definition: Compares the positive predictive value (PPV) across groups.
content.Use: Ensures consistent reliability of predictions across groups.
content.Justification: Essential to assess whether predictions are equitable.

content.Definition: Quantifies how biases in the training data are amplified in outputs.
content.Justification: Important for systems trained on imbalanced or historical data.

content.Definition: Measures the percentage of correct predictions for each at-risk group.
content.Use: Evaluates the overall correctness of the AI system.
content.Justification: Establishes a baseline for comparative functional correctness.

content.Metric: Precision, Recall, and F1-Score by Group
content.Definition: Standard classification metrics applied per group.
content.Use: Captures nuances in correctness, especially when data is imbalanced.
content.Justification: Aligns with ISO/IEC standards for evaluating functional correctness.

content.Metric: Mean Absolute Error (MAE) or RMSE by Group
content.Definition: Measures the error in continuous predictions, group-wise.
content.Use: Evaluates differences in functional accuracy for regression-based systems.
content.Justification: Necessary for regression-based systems where group-level performance matters.

content.Definition: Measures the stability of outputs across similar inputs within and across groups.
content.Use: Detects operational inconsistencies that may indicate bias.
content.Justification: Critical for ensuring fairness in dynamic conditions.

taskItems.title: 11. Dynamic Testing of the Model
taskItems.description: Conduct model testing on the ML model, including data pre-processing, to evaluate functional correctness. Test extreme data inputs for each at-risk group in order to identify variations in the robustness of the ML model that can result in unwanted bias.
taskItems.implementationGuidance:
Dynamic testing in this context comprises both conventional techniques, where given inputs generate expected outputs, and measurement approaches that show whether the system is behaving statistically as expected or as intended. These tests are designed based on the expected input data.

The degree to which test data are representative of the expected variety of input data provides a measurement of test coverage.

The process of obtaining the extreme data inputs can benefit from the participation of AI customers and AI users in test design, test execution, results assessment and interpretation.

For more information, see [ISO/IEC DTS 12791](#).
